event.title: 1727, John Digges, an Irish nobleman of Prince George's County, Maryland, obtained

data.event: In 1727, John Digges, an Irish nobleman of Prince George's County, Maryland, obtained a grant of 10,000 acres (40 km2) of land where Hanover is now located from Charles Calvert, the fourth Lord Baltimore.

In 1727, John Digges, an Irish nobleman of Prince George's County, Maryland, obtained a grant of 10,000 acres (40 km2) of land where Hanover is now located from Charles Calvert, the fourth Lord Baltimore.

event.title: was called Digges Choice, and in 1730

data.event: The area was called Digges Choice, and in 1730, a group of Catholics started the settlement that became known as the Conewego Settlement.

event.title: did not agree with each other, and the area that is now

data.event: At this time, the northern border of Maryland and the southern border of Pennsylvania did not agree with each other, and the area that is now Hanover was in the disputed area claimed by both states.

event.title: numerous disputes about property ownership from the 1730s until 1760

data.event: This led to numerous disputes about property ownership from the 1730s until 1760.
This line was surveyed between 1763 and 1767, and put an end to decades of disputes over rights and ownership.
